Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: At home, the child is learning daily manners, and the mother should provide guidance
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was kneeling on the living room floor, showing my son how to say “please” and “thank you” as he played with his blocks. He was fidgety, but I knew these small lessons mattered. My phone buzzed—an emergency alert from the construction site. The site-wide evacuation alarm had sounded. My heart pounded. I was supposed to be logged in remotely, monitoring the site’s progress, ready to respond to emergencies. Protocol was clear: drop everything, check in, and head to the muster point. But here I was, in the middle of teaching my son about kindness and respect, something I promised myself I’d never rush. My supervisor’s messages started coming in, each one more urgent. My son looked up at me, waiting for my next gentle correction. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in—my team counting on me to follow safety rules, my child needing my steady presence. I could feel the tension in my chest, torn between the rules of the site and the rules of my home, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed at the same time.
